Generation II.Gold: Although it always pretends to be a tree, its composition appears to be closer to a rock than a plant.
Generation II.Silver: It disguises itself as a tree to avoid attack. It hates water, so it will disappear if it starts raining.
Generation II.Crystal: If a tree branch shakes when there is no wind, it's a Sudowoodo , not a tree. It hides from the rain.
Generation II.Stadium 2: Although it always pretends to be a tree, its composition appears to be closer to a rock than a plant. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) It disguises itself as a tree to avoid attack. It hates water, so it will disappear if it starts raining. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Sudowoodo camouflages itself as a tree to avoid being attacked by enemies. However, because the forelegs remain green throughout the year, the Pok é mon is easily identified as a fake during the winter.
Generation III.Sapphire: Sudowoodo camouflages itself as a tree to avoid being attacked by enemies. However, because the forelegs remain green throughout the year, the Pok é mon is easily identified as a fake during the winter.
Generation III.Emerald: It mimics a tree to avoid being attacked by enemies. But since its forelegs remain green throughout the year, it is easily identified as a fake in the winter.
Generation III.FireRed: It disguises itself as a tree to avoid attack. It hates water, so it will disappear if it starts raining.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Although it always pretends to be a tree, its composition appears to be closer to a rock than a plant.

Generation IV.Diamond: Despite appearing to be a tree, its body is closer to rocks and stones. It is very weak to water.
Generation IV.Pearl: It stands along paths pretending to be a tree. If it starts raining, it seems to disappear.
Generation IV.Platinum: To avoid being attacked, it does nothing but mimic a tree. It hates water and flees from rain.
Generation IV.HeartGold: Although it always pretends to be a tree, its composition appears more similar to rock than to vegetation.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: It disguises itself as a tree to avoid attack. It hates water, so it will disappear if it starts raining.

Generation VII.Sun: To avoid attack, it mimics a tree. It will run off if splashed with water, which it hates.
Generation VII.Moon: Apparently, the larger the green parts of this Pokémon, the more collectors value it. It's a particular favorite among elderly people.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: It's so popular with the elderly that there's a magazine devoted to this Pokémon. Fans obsess over the particular length and angle of its arms.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: The result of its holding the same pose all the time is arms that have become supple yet strong.

Generation VIII.Sword: If a tree branch shakes when there is no wind, it's a Sudowoodo, not a tree. It hides from the rain.
Generation VIII.Shield: It disguises itself as a tree to avoid attack. It hates water, so it will disappear if it starts raining.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: Though it looks like a tree, its body is actually more like rock or stone. The Pokémon is very weak to water.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It stands along paths pretending to be a tree. If it starts raining, it seems to disappear.
Generation VIII.Legends: Arceus: Though it pretends to be a tree, it fails to fool even children. To the touch, its body feels more like rock than tree bark. Sudowoodo's extreme aversion to water merits special note.

Generation IX.Scarlet: Although it always pretends to be a tree, its composition appears more similar to rock than to vegetation.
Generation IX.Violet: To avoid being attacked, it does nothing but mimic a tree. It hates water and flees from rain.
